title: The Prize, More Than the Laureate
text:
Frankly, it’s the oldest question among those who judge art and measure men: can a bad man produce good art? (We all know, of course, that good men can — and like all kinds of men, usually do — produce bad art.)

The Nobel committee that has awarded Austrian playwright Peter Handke the Literature Nobel this year — along with Poland’s Olga Tokarczuk belatedly for the 2018 award — certainly seem to think so.

The quality of Handke’s works — his 1966 play Publikumsbeschimpfung (Offending the Audience) being quite representative of his practice of ring-fencing the world of theatre (read: art) from the world outside — hasn’t been brought to question even by those criticising the choice.

What has troubled some critics is that he is not just a public sympathiser of the late Yugoslavian and Serbian war criminal Slobodan Miloševic (Handke attended Miloševic ’s funeral in 2006), but also publicly stated that Sarajevo’s Muslims had ‘massacred themselves’ to apparently blame the Serbs of genocide during the Balkan War in the 1990s — a notion that is as fantastic as it is disgusting.

The problem, of course, lies in our idea of what an award like the Nobel Prize is — ironically a ‘good’ prize set up by the inventor of a ‘bad’ entity like dynamite, and owner, during his own lifetime, of the weapons manufacturer Bofors.

One of the staunchest critics of the Nobel giving the award to Handke, writer Salman Rushdie, himself knows what it means to be considered a ‘bad man and, therefore, by extension, a bad writer’.

His 1988 novel The Satanic Verses was not allowed to be printed in India by the Rajiv Gandhi government, as it was considered by enough thin-skinned, loudmouths to be denigrating Islam. This prohibition in India subsequently leading to the fatwa on February 14, 1989, from Iran’s Ayatollah Khomeini, which actually called for the writer’s death.

Much of the so-called ‘liberal’ criticism to this day against Rushdie’s book has been not about it being ‘blasphemous’, of course. Liberals lurrv blasphemy, and I certainly do.

It remains a ‘bad book’ because it was apparently a ‘bad novel’ — a convenient piggyback ride and liberal sleight-of-hand that conflates ‘bad art’ with a perceived ‘bad man’.

This conflation has been around for a long time, with noted examples like the disturbing prospect of having to deal with the stunning images from Nazi propaganda filmmaker Leni Riefenstahl’s 1935 Triumph of the Will and 1938 Olympia; or, Soviet cinema grandmaster Sergei Eisenstein’s propaganda 1928 film, October, and the glorious 1944 epic, Ivan the Terrible, Part 1, a personal favourite of Josef Stalin and mine.

These are great art that makes liberal purveyors of the liberal arts uncomfortable — the sort of thing that, coming from the other end of the ideological and aesthetic spectrum, ‘outrages’ conservatives, who usually have the luxury of demanding that these blasphemous/sentimentshurting/anti-national/anti-community (choose your poison)… works be banned or, even better, destroyed Bamyan Buddha-style.

This is not to stretch moral or aesthetic relativism to a ludicrous extreme. After all, Handke’s support of the architect of an established genocide cannot be put at par with, say, Rushdie’s ‘poetic licence’.

But whether it’s the confusion of retrospectively finding moral and ethical faults with great writers like Bankimchandra Chattopadhyay (for being an inspiration much later to the Hindu Right for his 1882 novel Anandamath, famously the source of the ‘lyrics’ of ‘Vande Mataram’), or great composers like the genuinely antisemitic Richard Wagner (for inspiring Germany’s Nazi Party’s racist ideology decades later), or great singer-songwriters like Steven Morrissey (whose anti-immigrant and pro-Brexit stand has become loud enough for admirers to press the pause button even when playing back catalogues) —or contemporary ‘good writers, with bad values’ like the American poet Ezra Pound, who was an open sympathiser of fascism, and Handke himself… it is tough to separate the man and his artistic works, something that the Nobel Committee may, in its utter devotion to aesthetic objectivity, may have managed.

Perhaps what is being judged is not so much the Nobel laureate but the Nobel Prize itself. Remember, the 1953 Nobel Prize in Literature went to Winston Churchill, who only 10 years before was the architect of the 1943 Bengal famine that saw some three million Indians perish because of his decision to refuse emergency food supplies be diverted to starving Indians from stockpiles for already well-supplied Allied troops in Greece and Yugoslavia.

The only way, perhaps, to deal with the discomfort of some of the ‘poor’ choices made by this recognised and still-prestigious award that is the Nobel is to take it less seriously. Especially at a time when awards and recognitions have proliferated enough for one to tip one’s hat at some choices, and give the cold shoulder to the more ‘problematic ones’.
